verses.text: The word of the LORD that came to Joel, son of Pethuel:
verses.comment: Joel is introduced as a prophet who receives God's word, echoing the calling of other prophets (Jeremiah, Ezekiel). The strong emphasis on God's direct revelation points to a tradition of divinely guided leadership in the history of Israel, as seen elsewhere in scripture.

verses.text: Hear this, you elders, and listen, all inhabitants of the land. Has anything like this happened in your days, or in the days of your ancestors?
verses.comment: Joel calls upon both leadership and the people, linking the disaster ahead to the tradition of remembrance. This reflects the biblical pattern of handing down God's works generation to generation (see Ps. 78:5).

verses.text: Tell your children about it, and let your children tell theirs, and their children to another generation.
verses.comment: Joel stresses the communal memory of God's actions—a command repeated throughout scripture. This transmission reflects the importance of tradition and continuity in the faith (see Deuteronomy 6:7).

verses.text: What the cutting locust left, the swarming locust has eaten. What the swarming locust left, the hopping locust has eaten. What the hopping locust left, the consuming locust has eaten.
verses.comment: The devastation of successive locust plagues recalls the plagues of Egypt, often interpreted as a sign of judgment and a call to repentance. The pattern suggests that when hardship comes in waves, it often points to a deeper spiritual reality requiring response.

verses.text: Wake up, you drunkards, and weep; wail, all drinkers of wine, for the new wine is cut off from your mouths.
verses.comment: This rebuke draws a direct connection between the loss of material goods (like wine) and spiritual wakefulness. There is a parallel warning that misplaced indulgence leads to loss, echoing wisdom literature.

verses.text: For a nation has come up against my land, strong and without number; its teeth are lion’s teeth, and it has the fangs of a lioness.
verses.comment: The locusts are metaphorically described as a nation, suggesting either a literal invading force or the completeness of the destruction. The lion imagery reinforces the ferocity of the judgment. This anticipates later apocalyptic writings with symbolic language.

verses.text: It has laid waste my vine and stripped my fig tree bare; it has broken them down and thrown them away, their branches are white.
verses.comment: The vine and fig tree are symbols of Israel's prosperity and blessing (see Isaiah 5:5-6), so their destruction is significant. There is an implication of spiritual withering, linking the physical loss to a spiritual reality.

verses.text: Lament like a young woman dressed in sackcloth mourning the betrothed of her youth.
verses.comment: The call to lamenting echoes the call to deep repentance found in the prophets. The image of lost betrothal might be linked to Israel's spiritual relationship and covenant with God, prefiguring themes of betrothal and spiritual union later in scripture.

verses.text: The grain offering and the drink offering are cut off from the house of the LORD; the priests mourn, those who minister to the LORD.
verses.comment: With the cessation of offerings, the spiritual life of Israel is interrupted. This loss of sacrificial worship points to the centrality of liturgical rites and ordained ministry in maintaining the people's relationship with God.

verses.text: The fields are ruined, the ground mourns; for the grain is destroyed, the new wine dried up, the oil fails.
verses.comment: Joel describes creation itself participating in the sorrow. The loss of grain, wine, and oil touches on both the physical sustenance and the materials for worship, showing a unity between creation and divine service.

verses.text: Despair, you farmers, wail, you vine dressers, for the wheat and the barley; because the harvest of the field has perished.
verses.comment: This lament for earthly loss stands as a mirror to spiritual loss. The harvest is often seen as both a symbol of God’s blessing and as a parable for spiritual fruitfulness (see Matt. 9:37).

verses.text: The vine has dried up, and the fig tree withered; the pomegranate, palm, and apple—all the trees of the field—have dried up, and joy has disappeared from the sons of men.
verses.comment: The loss of joy is linked with physical devastation. The imagery suggests a deep, spiritual bankruptcy that is connected to the absence of life's blessings and worship.

verses.text: Put on sackcloth and lament, O priests. Wail, O ministers of the altar. Come and spend the night in sackcloth, you who serve my God; for the grain offering and the drink offering are withheld from the house of your God.
verses.comment: Joel highlights the special duty of ordained ministers to intercede and mourn for the people. The focus on the altar and offerings points to the particular importance of an organized ministry and liturgy in addressing spiritual crisis.

verses.text: Proclaim a fast, call a solemn assembly, gather the elders and all the inhabitants of the land to the house of the LORD your God, and cry out to the LORD.
verses.comment: Joel commands public, liturgical repentance—fasting and assembly. This organized response is both literal and spiritual, as it points toward the practice of gathering the whole community for prayer and return to God.

verses.text: Alas for the day! For the day of the LORD is near, and as destruction from the Almighty it comes.
verses.comment: This anticipates the prophetic 'Day of the LORD,' a theme of judgment and renewal in the Old Testament. Its proximity urges readiness, and later finds fulfillment in eschatological warnings of Christ (see Matt. 24:30).

verses.text: Is not food cut off before our eyes, joy and gladness from the house of our God?
verses.comment: The loss of sustenance and gladness from God's house is not only physical but spiritual. Joy in worship disappears when relationship with God is broken, emphasizing the connection between visible signs and invisible realities.

verses.text: The seeds decay under the clods, the storehouses lie desolate, the barns are torn down, for the grain is dried up.
verses.comment: Here, the agricultural devastation serves as a sign of spiritual drought. The physical misuse or loss of God's providence hints at a spiritual bankruptcy, which is restored through faithful reliance on God’s promise.

verses.text: How the animals groan! The herds of cattle are perplexed because they have no pasture; even the flocks of sheep suffer.
verses.comment: Creation itself groans under judgment (see Romans 8:22). The suffering of animals underscores the all-encompassing nature of the affliction, awaiting renewal through divine intervention.

verses.text: To you, O LORD, I cry, for fire has devoured the pastures of the wilderness and flame has burned all the trees of the field.
verses.comment: Joel intercedes directly to God, showing the importance of personal and communal prayer in times of crisis. The image of fire parallels God’s cleansing judgments and the need for reparation.

verses.text: Even the wild animals pant for you, for the streams of water are dried up and fire has devoured the pastures of the wilderness.
verses.comment: All creation longs for God’s restoration, paralleling Psalmist’s cry for God (Psalm 42:1). The spiritual implication is that the proper order—heaven, earth, humanity and creation—is restored only when all turn back to God.
